narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Zhemin Xuan  Zhemin was available on Mondays during office hours and was patient with questions. I felt that he knew the material well and seems to be very knowledgable about the subject, but sometimes I did not feel like the explanations to our questions were clear.

Instructor: Zhemin Xuan  Zhemin made himself available when we had problem sets, however not before the final exam. His open TF hours were useful, but in general he is quiet and this made him slightly unapproachable.

Instructor: Zhemin Xuan  Office hours, especially before problem sets, were very good. However, it might be nice to reach out before exams to offer more help to students, and to note issues that multiple students ran into on the previous exam.
Instructor: Zhemin Xuan  Zhemin was very friendly, approachable and helpful, but it was difficult to find him for office hours or to pick up graded problem sets.
Instructor: Zhemin Xuan  He did a good job. He knew the material and was accessible.
Instructor: Zhemin Xuan  Great attitude and helpful, but somewhat bad timing and slow to grade problem sets/ midterms.
Instructor: Zhemin Xuan  Zhemin was very helpful in office hours.
Instructor: Zhemin Xuan  He was a great resource when doing the homework assignments. He came to section prepared and was able to answer all of my questions thoroughly.

Instructor: Zhemin Xuan  We did not interact heavily with the teaching assistant in this course, but he seemed competent. One issue was that he did not make an effort to complete grading our first homework assignment before the first exam - we were told we could pick up this assignment on the day of the exam, only a few hours before it was administered

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The text book Biogeochemistry of Forested Ecosystems was very useful, other readings, less so. More frequent problem sets would have aided learning more of the material. Field trips organization would be improved by setting a time and date in advance, rather than with 1 day of notice (or less in some cases).
Class pace was too fast. Concepts were not always clearly explained.

The field trips were so disorganized, often announced just a day or two before we had to go. It made scheduling for the class terrible--a lot of us have other classes and jobs that we can't just cancel for a field trip where we probably won't really be learning anything useful anyway. This disorganization carried over into our schedule for exams. They were often announced a week or so in advance, which is not really enough time to study for a class where so much material is covered. And for the second exam Gabe cancelled it TWO HOURS before we were supposed to take it. Completely disrespectful. All of us students have the common decency to show up for your class (to which you come disorganized) and study hours for your exam, only to be told 2 hours before that we're going on a field trip instead. Lectures were hard to follow, as Gabe would jump from concept to concept, without much explanation in between, only to return to previous concepts. He comes to class with notes, but still can't seem to keep a linear trajectory for his lectures.

Instructor for this course was highly disorganized and presented the material in a fragmentary way, without making an effort to construct an understandable narrative. The actual information content of the course as a whole was relatively average, but the scattered approach to presenting this material made it harder to learn than it should be. For the first half of the course, the instructor presented material at a breakneck speed, often not giving students time to successfully write notes from his primarily verbal descriptions of diagrams or construct questions. At times the instructor simply did not notice that students had questions, and had to be asked to back up and explain topics. Instructor often seemed to be unaware of the time, frantically checking the clock, out of breadth as he paused momentarily. After rushing through the first half of the course, and exclaiming about how far ahead we were, the instructor got sick for two complete weeks, which placed us exactly back on the usual schedule of the course. The course had only a single homework assignment that was required to turn in, and was not organized in a timely manner that would make it useful as study feedback for the midterm. This assignment was handed back on the day of the first midterm. The 2nd homework assignment was DUE on the day of the 2nd midterm, again reducing its utility as a learning tool. Overall, the subject matter of the course is very interesting, but the presentation was very disappointing to myself and also many other students. The purpose of taking a course is for an instructor to convey information in a structured way. If the learning done in a course could happen by students simply doing independent readings, attending the course itself becomes a waste of time. Professor Benoit is a highly intelligent man who has a lot to offer to his students. However to make his courses worthwhile uses of his student's time and money, he needs to put more effort into conceptualizing his course material in a well structured format.

13-16 Gabe is very accessible in class. He is more than happy to stop and answer questions when students ask them, and usually his responses really do help clarify. However, the format of the class was difficult to follow. Gabe would provide packets of the powerpoint slides, but these were almost always out of order with slides missing, so it was hard to find the slide he was talking about in class. He kept jumping between slides and the whiteboard, and it took a while to figure out what I should be looking at. I started to get the hang of his teaching style towards the end of the semester which made things run a bit smoother. I'd say a lot of the concepts covered in the course I had already learned in other classes here, but it was helpful for me to take this class to tie everything together and to really solidify my grasp of the concepts.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I feel I am walking away with a better understanding of the chemistry of pollutants in the environment. Field trips were good and applicable to the course material.
I enjoyed the material, its very interesting topic.
The groundwater contamination section was my personal favorite. I also liked the overview of where contaminants come from, as well as which are most harmful.
Well taught course. Dr. Benoit is a good lecturer and very responsive to student questions and comments. The field trips were helpful and I learned a lot from the problem sets.
The course covered practical and useful information. It was a good balance between applied and academic.
biogeochemistry and pollution is an important and fascinating topic. the fact this course exists at Yale is a very important contribution to our learning.
It is a topic I am interested in, and very very applicable for folks who may want to work in water resources management later on.
Field trips

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Develop a schedule for field trips, midterms, and assignments in advance so students can plan accordingly.

Course organization and presentation of information could be improved. Breaking up the material into distinct and succinct portions would be an improvement over simply listing the material as a string of equations and facts. It seemed very disjointed this way and was difficult to synthesize.
The (waste)water treatment section of the class was too disjointed. I don't feel that I have a broad understanding of treatment technologies.

More structure in the lectures/lecture slides would have been very helpful. For instance, slide or figure titles and some written commentary on the slides would have helped me follow the lectures better. I learned more from the problem sets than the bibliography assignment and although it would have been more work, I would have preferred an extra problem set over the bibliography assignment.
Delivery of information in course could be better organized.
scheduling.

Structuring material into a narrative. Instructor relies far to heavily on powerpoint slides. Instructor needs to construct quality homework assignments that function as an aid to learning, and reinforce the material he is presenting in the lectures. These homework assignments should also show reasonable match with the exams. For instance, if the final exam is going to include evaluating an environmental assessment, create a homework assignment that is similar. This helps students tune the conceptual tools they are developing and become experienced in doing this sort of analysis.
The presentation of material could use a lot of work. It felt a bit disjointed (see previous comment).

Field trips need to be shared with students at least a week in advance. Several field trips were announced the day before resulting some students needing to change previous commitments in order to attend the trip. Though I understood how the lectures on quality control and lab procedures tying into to the overall course at the end, the actual lectures did not seem relevant at the time since the course did not have a lab component and seemed more appropriate for a methods course as they were general best practices.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
N/A
There is not discussion section for this course, though one would be useful.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I think this course was a good introduction to other courses I want to take later, like Organic Pollutants and Advanced Biogeochemistry (obviously).
I took the course as an elective.
Core environmental science course.
Biogeochemistry is a primary interest of mine, which is what makes the low quality of this course so sad.
Helpful for those interested in water / science. Ties in nicely with physical science, soil science, coastal ecosystems, etc.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Preparation for my thesis in this field.
To get a broad background in chemistry and common pollutants, so I can use that info in my research.
I took the course because of my specific research interests.
Academic interest.
Essential to understanding science surrounding water quality.
My advisor told me to.
Because biogeochemistry is a major interest of mine.
relevant to my field of interest
To fulfill the requirements of the Water Resource concentration and to set a foundation in the science of water quality.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, I feel like I got a lot out of this course.
Yes, I think so.
Mostly yes - Although I still feel like I can't quite put it all into context. This could possibly be helped by more structured slides.
Yes.
More or less. I feel like I still have a lot of outstanding questions.
Nope. Definitely didn't learn much new material. And the concepts that were new to me weren't necessarily presented in a way I could understand them.
Not really. Much of the information I learned resides as scattered facts in my mind rather than forming into a crystal of knowledge.
Generally yes
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Good to discuss the subject matter to enhance understanding.
Getting together with other students was profoundly useful in rebuilding the information presented in class into a coherent structure.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Ask more questions in class! It helps everyone.
Be prepared to have to work hard to make sense of everything.
Don't take this course. Take Organic Pollutants instead. I decided to take this instead and regret my decision.
Consider taking a different course, or just doing your own readings on this subject.
Very valuable content, but don't expect it to be your favorite class. The workload was not overwhelming, just a problem set and a few exams plus a minor assignment on creating a bibliography.
Prepare for class with the assigned readings to keep up with lecture.
